llm_processed_output.source_summary: This academic paper, published in the Journal of Islamic Numismatics Center (Egypt), meticulously examines the Khazrunid dynasty, a Berber dynasty that ruled a portion of Morocco during the Middle Ages.  It focuses on the numismatic evidence, specifically Khazrunid gold coins, to understand the political dynamics of the time, particularly the conflicts between the Khazrunids and the Umayyad caliphate of Spain, and the Fatimids. The author critically analyzes existing numismatic studies and historical accounts, such as Ibn Khaldun, to correct inaccuracies, clarify the reign of different Khazrunid rulers (including Khazrun, Wanudin, and Mas'ud), and provide a nuanced understanding of the political control over Sijilmasa.  The paper presents a new classification of Khazrunid gold coins based on an unpublished collection, offering detailed analysis of different types of coins, their characteristics, dates (where possible), and relationships to contemporary rulers, demonstrating the significance of numismatics in understanding historical events. The study also highlights the complexities and challenges of historical reconstruction, especially in relation to the lack of detailed information in some historical texts.
extracted_key_facts: The Khazrunid dynasty, a Berber dynasty, ruled a part of Morocco in the Middle Ages.
They were a branch of Maghrawa of Zenata, considered a major Moroccan tribe.
The Khazrunids came to power in Sijilmasa in 367 AH / 977 AD, ruling in the name of the Spanish Umayyad Caliph Hisham II Al-Mu’ayyd.
Almost all of Morocco was ruled by the Fatimids, but the Spanish Umayyads struck coins in Sijilmasa.
Sijilmasa was a crucial center of communication and commerce between the Mediterranean, the Sahara, and the Orient, and was a pivotal city in the gold trade.
The Khazrunids ruled Sijilmasa from 367 AH / 977 AD to 445 AH / 1053 AD, except during temporary Fatimid and Zirid incursions.
A revolt of Ziri in Fas temporarily disrupted Khazrunid control around 388 AH/ 999 AD.
Wanudin became an independent ruler in Sijilmasa after 390 AH / 999 AD, according to Ibn Khaldun.
The Al-Moravids conquered Sefrou in 455 AH / 1063 AD, leading to the extermination of the Khazrunid family and followers.
Ibn Khaldun's accounts, the primary source for Moroccan history, contained contradictions regarding the Khazrunids' reigns and lack details for the period.

The paper identifies that the Khazrunid dynasty had more than three rulers as previously thought. Two additional rulers, Muhammad son of Mas'ud and Mas'ud son of Muhammad, are included in the new analysis based on Ibn Al-Khatib.
The study corrects previous interpretations of Wanudin's reign and expansion, pointing out inaccuracies in existing numismatic studies.
The author details problems in previous numismatic studies related to the scarcity of dated Khazrunid coins, issues with clipped margins, and the misreading of inscriptions (e.g., "Wazir"/"Wanudin").
The study identifies new types of Khazrunid gold coins and provides detailed descriptions of their inscriptions, often referring to Hisham II and Sulayman Al-Musta'in.
The author corrects previous errors in identifying the rulers who struck coins and suggests new attributions based on coin inscriptions.
The paper uses numismatic evidence (coins) to refine and correct historical accounts of the Khazrunid period.
